sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application is a memorization aid following the Leitner flashcard system. You can use &app; for both long-term and short-term learning.

sect2.title: What is a Flashcard?
sect2.para: A physical flashcard is a small card with a word or question written on one side and the translation or answer written on the other. Repeatedly picking up flashcards and trying to remember what's written on the reverse side is a good way to memorize things.

sect2.title: What is the Leitner Flashcard System?
sect2.para: This software uses a spaced repetition system devised by Sebastian Leitner to make efficient use of study time.

In this system, you have a series of boxes numbered from one up to, let's say, eight. You begin by placing all of your flashcards in box number one. Test yourself with box one's cards daily. If you can't remember what's written on the reverse of a card, return it to box number one. If you can remember what's written on the reverse, drop the card into box number two. The cards in box two are tested every three days. Any of those that you remember can be moved to box number three, which you'll only look at every seven days. And so on, up to box eight, with increasing time intervals per box. Whenever you can't remember what's written on the back of a card, that card returns to box number one, regardless of which box it was last in.
As a result, your time is spent with the cards that need it the most.
Electronic flashcard programs such as &app; automate this system.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose Education i GNU it Flashcard Trainer.
Execute the following command: ignuit [FILENAME]

sect2.title: Your Flashcard Collection
sect2.para: To use &app;, you'll need some flashcards. Here are your options:

listitem.para: Use the built-in card editor to create your own flashcards.
Check the &app; homepage for flashcard files submitted by users.
Import flashcards from another program.

sect2.para: The first option is often the best: the cards will fit your needs, not somebody else's.

sect2.title: Long Term Memorization
sect2.para: For the long term memorization of your flashcards, you should aim to quiz yourself once a day with the Quiz menu's Expired Cards or New and Expired Cards option selected.

When the quiz window opens, check that its Record option is enabled. That way the program will keep track of which cards you know and which cards you have trouble with, and quiz you accordingly over time.
When you get to the end of a quiz, use the controls to go back and review your answers before closing the quiz window.

sect2.title: Cramming or Drilling
sect2.para: If you'd like to drill yourself, or if you want to memorize information quickly for an upcoming test or exam, use the Quiz menu to select cards for testing. You'll probably be more interested in the All Cards, New Cards, or Selected Cards options than either of the Expired Cards options.
Now quiz yourself repeatedly using Begin Quiz in Drill Mode from the Quiz menu.

In Drill Mode, the repeated quizzing won't affect the box numbers or expiry dates of the quizzed cards. Only the order of the cards in the card pane will be affected, with the difficult ones rising to the top.

tip.para: After adding a group of new cards to a file, it can be helpful to quiz yourself a few times in Drill Mode.
If you're learning a language, it's important to learn phrases, not just individual words. Short phrases help with grammar as well as vocabulary.
For cards that are really hard to remember, nothing beats repeatedly writing things down on scrap paper.

sect1.title: The Main Window
sect1.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed:
The main window is divided into two panes.

listitem.para: The category pane displays a list of all categories in the file. Below the category pane are controls for adding and removing categories.
You can rename a category by double-clicking its title, or by pressing ENTER on a selected category, or via the Category Properties dialog.
Right-clicking in the category pane brings up a context menu with available options.
You can search the category pane by giving it keyboard focus and typing in your query.
The card pane displays a list of all cards in the selected category. The card pane is also where search results are listed. Below the card pane are controls for editing, adding and removing cards.
You can specify which columns are shown in the card pane by right-clicking on the column titles.
You can search the card pane's "Front" column by selecting it and then typing in your query. More detailed searches can be made by selecting Find... from the Edit menu.

tip.para: If you accidentally remove a card, you can retrieve it via the Edit menu's Recently Removed Cards option. The removed card can then be dragged to the category of your choice.

By default the program manages the order of the cards in the card pane itself, moving difficult cards to the top of the window. To prevent this, right-click on relevant category titles and select Preserve Card Order.

sect1.title: The File Properties Dialog
sect1.para: To add or edit information about a file, or to choose a card style, select Properties from the File menu.
The available card styles are:

listitem.para: All text is centre justified. A large font is used for keywords and a small font for subsequent lines. This is the default setting for new files.
All text is left or right justified, depending on the language. Keywords use a large font, subsequent lines use a small font.
All text is left or right justified, depending on the language, and displayed using a small font.

sect1.title: The Card Editor Window
sect1.para: To add a card to a selected category, either select Add Card from the Card menu, or press the Add Card button located below the card pane. The Card Editor window will appear.
The card editor contains the following elements:

listitem.para: Like a physical flashcard, each card in &app; has two sides that need filling in. The side displayed by the text editor depends on the state of the Flip Card toggle.

The first line of text on each side of a card is treated as the "keyword". Subsequent lines are treated as descriptive or example text. There's no visible difference in the card editor window, but in the quiz window keywords and example text are usually displayed using different fonts.

To help organise your cards, they can optionally be marked with the tags of your choice. Tags are separated by spaces. The tag bar can be switched on and off via the Card menu. If you want to modify the tags of several cards at a time, use the Tag Manager. It's available via the Card menu of &app;'s main window.
This button toggles the display of statistics for the current card.
This button adds a new card to the current category.

This button moves the current card to the trash. The trash is emptied when the program closes. Until then, you can retrieve accidentally removed cards via the Recently Removed Cards option in the main window's Edit menu.
This button takes you to the previous card. If the editor reaches the start of the list, it wraps to the last card.
This toggle button switches the text entry box between front and back views of the current card.
This button takes you to the next card. If the editor reaches the end of the list, it wraps to the first card.

sect2.title: Card Editor Markup

textobject.phrase: Example of markup used in the &app; Card Editor window.

sect2.para: In case you'd like to tweak things a little, &app; recognizes the following simple HTML-like tags:

entry.para: This self-closing tag inserts a line break. It could be used to split a keyword over multiple lines, for example.

This self-closing tag is used to attach a picture or an audio file. The "type" attribute can be either "image" or "sound". The "src" attribute specifies a filename, either as an absolute path, or relative to the directory containing the flashcard file. The optional "alt" attribute provides some text to display in the card pane. Please note that it's generally best to use relative filenames in your cards. For example, use sounds/hello.ogg rather than /home/user/flashcards/sounds/hello.ogg.
This is the style used for the keyword of each card. Since &app; handles keywords automatically, you will probably not need this tag.
This element has no effect unless used with attributes. Available attributes are fg="..." and bg="...", which control foreground and background colour respectively.
Any markup placed between these tags will be displayed as plain text.
This element uses LaTeX to display a mathematical formula inline. See the section on Ignuit and LaTeX for details.
This element uses LaTeX to process whatever text you specify. See the section on Ignuit and LaTeX for details.

sect2.para: Apart from the two LaTex-specific elements, all of the elements above accept fg="..." and bg="..." attributes. These attributes control foreground and background colour respectively. For example, this would produce bold red text on a yellow background.

tip.para: If you'd like the Flip Card toggle to retain its state when you switch to the next or previous card, activate the Sticky Flips option in the editor window's Card menu.
If you find you've made a card with the faces accidentally reversed, select Switch Sides from the editor window's Edit menu.
If you accidentally remove a card, select Recently Removed Cards from the main window's Edit menu, then drag the card back to its original category.

sect1.title: Quiz Menu Options
sect1.para: The Quiz menu lets you choose between various options before opening the quiz window.
The quiz menu contains the following items:

listitem.para: This item opens the quiz window and begins a quiz. This is the same as the Quiz button on the main window toolbar.
This item opens the quiz window in Drill Mode, letting you test yourself without affecting the scheduling of your cards.
This option causes cards from all categories to be included in the quiz.
This option limits the quiz to cards in the currently selected category.
This option causes every card in the file or current category (depending on the previous two options) to be included in the quiz.
This option limits the quiz to cards that have not been quizzed in the past.
This option limits the quiz to cards whose expiry dates have been reached or passed. These are the cards &app; thinks you should be quizzed on.
This option limits the quiz to untested cards and cards whose expiry dates have been reached or passed. This is the default setting.
This option limits the quiz to user-flagged cards.
This option limits the quiz to cards currently selected in the main window's card pane.
This option tests you using the front side of each card.
This option tests you using the back side of each card.
This option tests you using either the front or the back of each card.
Checking this box prevents the cards from being shuffled. During the quiz they'll be presented in the order listed in the card pane.

sect1.title: The Quiz Window
sect1.para: After selecting Begin Quiz from the main window's toolbar or Quiz menu, the Quiz window opens.
The quiz window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: This area displays the front of the card by default. Try to remember what's on the back, then check by using the Flip Card toggle. If you're correct, mark the card as Known. Otherwise, mark it as Unknown.
This is an optional text entry area where you can type in your answer before flipping the card to check it. The answer bar can be switched on and off via the Card menu.
This button toggles the display of statistics for the current card.

This check-box tells &app; whether or not the results of the current quiz should be used to calculate new expiry dates for the cards involved. For normal use (long term learning), this option should be enabled. For repeated drilling, it should be disabled.
This button takes you to the previous card. You're free to move through the cards and make changes as you wish.
This button takes you to the next card. You're free to move through the cards and make changes as you wish.
This button tells &app; that you have trouble with the current card.
If the card is already marked as Unknown, pressing this button again returns the card to its unmarked state. For convenience, marking an unmarked card immediately moves you to the next card.
Flips the card over so you can check your memory.
Since the Known and Unknown buttons automatically move you to the next card, use the Flip Card button before marking the card as Known or Unknown.
This button tells &app; that you know what's written on the back of the current card.
If the card is already marked as Known, pressing this button again returns the card to its unmarked state. For convenience, marking an unmarked card immediately moves you to the next card.

tip.para: After a quiz, but before closing the quiz window, use the Previous Card and Next Card buttons to review your cards and choices. Reviewing quizzes this way really does help things stick.
It's fine to close the quiz window without getting to the end of the quiz. Only the cards that you actually mark are recorded.

sect1.title: The Preferences Dialog
sect1.para: To configure &app;, choose Preferences from the Edit menu.
The Preferences dialog contains three tabs: the Appearance tab, the Schedules tab, and the Other Options tab.

sect2.title: The Appearance Tab

figure.title: The Appearance tab in the &app; Preferences dialog

textobject.phrase: Shows the Appearance tab in the &app; Preferences dialog.

sect2.para: The Appearance tab lets you set the colours and font used to display cards in the card editor and quiz windows.

As well as a foreground colour shared by all cards, card background colours can be set for plain (unmarked) cards, cards marked as "known", and cards marked as "unknown". The background colour for special messages (e.g. "End of quiz" or "No cards are available") can also be set.

sect2.title: The Schedules Tab

figure.title: The Schedules tab in the &app; Preferences dialog

textobject.phrase: Shows the Schedules tab in the &app; Preferences dialog.

sect2.para: The Schedules tab lets you specify how many days to wait between re-testing the cards belonging to each box. Please see the Introduction for a description of how boxes work.

figure.title: The Other Options tab in the &app; Preferences dialog

textobject.phrase: Shows the Other Options tab in the &app; Preferences dialog.

sect2.title: Importing a file
sect2.para: To import cards from another program, select Import... from the File menu. In the Import dialog, select the appropriate Import Filter. By default, imported cards are added to the currently open file. If this isn't what you want, select New from the File menu before importing the cards.

sect2.title: Copying cards between files
sect2.para: There are two ways to copy cards from one file to another.
The first option is to select the cards you're interested in, copy them via the Edit menu, open the destination file, then paste them into whichever category you like.

The second option is to import an entire file into the currently open file (taking care to choose the right import filter). All of the cards from the imported file will be added to the current file. Whether or not the imported cards retain their original categories depends on the format of the imported file.

sect2.title: Encoding for imported files
sect2.para: All imported files should be uncompressed and in the UTF-8 (or plain ASCII) encoding. The gunzip and file-roller programs can uncompress files, and the iconv program can help you convert encodings.

sect2.title: Reversing the faces of imported cards
sect2.para: You can reverse the faces (i.e. switch the fronts and backs) of imported cards by selecting them in the card pane and then choosing Switch Sides from the Card menu.

sect2.title: Comma Separated Value (CSV) and Tab Separated Value (TSV) files
sect2.para: &app; can import (and export) CSV and TSV files. Each newline delimited row represents a single card. Each row consists of up to three fields: the card's front text, its back text, and (optionally) its category. These fields are separated by a comma (for a CSV file) or by a tab (for a TSV file). Here's an example CSV file:
sect2.programlisting: Front text for card one,Back text for card one,Example category Front text for card two,Back text for card two,Example category
sect2.para: If a field's text includes a comma (for CSV) or a tab (for TSV), that field must be enclosed by double quotes.
sect2.programlisting: "Front text, card one","Back text, card one",Example category
sect2.para: If a field includes a double quote character, that character must be escaped by preceding it with another double quote character.
If a field includes a newline character, that field must be enclosed by double quote characters.

sect2.title: Adding support for XML-based file formats
sect2.para: Additional XML-based file formats can be supported by adding XSLT files to $prefix/share/ignuit/import, where the program will automatically find and use them. The export filters work the same way. See the existing XSLT files for examples.

sect2.title: Keyboard navigation
sect2.para: Using the keyboard instead of the mouse can speed you up a lot, especially in the editor and quiz windows. Most functions have keyboard shortcuts listed in the menus. You can also use the Tab, Cursor, and Enter keys to navigate and select items.

sect2.title: Search tips
sect2.para: In the Find dialog, searching without a query will find cards with blank sides (or with no tags, if the Tags option is selected). Regular expressions can be useful with tags. For example, the query "(apples|oranges)" will find cards tagged with either "apples" OR "oranges". To find cards with embedded images or audio, select the "Include markup in search" option, and use "<embed" as the query text.
The toolbar's Previous Category button will return you to the category you were in before searching.

sect2.title: Flagging cards
sect2.para: Cards can be flagged by pressing CTRL-8 in the card pane, the card editor, or the quiz window. Flagging is a way to mark cards for easy identification. You might flag a card if you notice a spelling mistake during a quiz, so that you can find and correct it later. Or you might flag cards that you'd like to have double-checked by somebody else. What you do with flagged cards is up to you. You can get a list of all flagged cards by selecting Find Flagged Cards from the Edit menu.

sect2.title: Absolute vs relative filenames
sect2.para: When using the <embed type="..." src="..." alt="..."/> element to attach images and sounds to cards, the filenames you give can be either absolute (e.g. /home/user/flashcards/sounds/hello.ogg) or relative (e.g. sounds/hello.ogg). Relative filenames are relative to the parent flashcard file. Using relative filenames rather than absolute filenames makes it much easier to move (or share) your flashcards without breakage.

sect2.title: Troubleshooting
sect2.para: If &app; seems to be misbehaving, try running it from the command line and watching for error messages there.

sect1.title: Bugs and Plans
